metadata.data_source: Longitudinal assessment data (first to last assessment comparison)

children.note: Estimated based on average household size

tier1_conservative.methodology: Measured annual wage gains only. No projections.
tier1_conservative.appropriate_audience: Skeptical funders, evaluators, legislators wanting floor estimates
caveats: Assumes all measured wage gains persist for at least 1 year
Does not account for what would have happened without program (no RCT yet)
Uses full $25M investment as denominator, not spent-to-date

tier2_taxpayer.methodology: Tax revenue from wage gains + estimated benefits cost avoidance by FPL tier
tier2_taxpayer.appropriate_audience: State legislators, TANF administrators, taxpayer advocates

benefits_savings.caveat: Estimates based on FPL thresholds, not tracked benefit terminations

caveats: Benefits savings are ESTIMATES based on FPL thresholds
Actual savings depend on individual benefit receipt and recertification timing
Does not account for what would have happened without program
TN-specific benefit levels used (lower than national average)

tier3_lifecycle.methodology: Annual wage gains projected over working lifetime with discount rate

assumptions.note: Age data not available; using 25 years as conservative estimate

full_persistence.assumption: Wage gains persist unchanged for 25 years

with_fade.assumption: Wage gains fade: 100% years 1-5, 80% years 6-10, 60% years 11-25

caveats: PROJECTION: Assumes wage gains persist; research shows effects often fade
Working years assumed at 25; actual varies by participant age
Without RCT, cannot claim causation—association only
Sensitivity analysis recommended for key assumptions

tier4_intergenerational.methodology: Includes research-based projections of child outcome improvements
tier4_intergenerational.research_basis: Chetty et al.: $1,000 childhood income increase -> 1.3% higher adult earnings
caveats: HIGHLY SPECULATIVE: Intergenerational effects are research-based projections, not measured
Chetty research based on different populations; applicability to rural TN uncertain
Effects won't be observable for 15-20 years
Should not be primary ROI cited; use for 'comprehensive potential' framing
tier4_intergenerational.red_flag: WARNING: ROI >10:1 may indicate overclaiming. Verify assumptions.

sensitivity_analysis.methodology: Varies key assumptions to show range of outcomes

attribution.note: RCT will reveal actual attribution; Building Nebraska Families showed 0% attribution

wage_persistence.note: Research shows workforce gains often fade; long-term follow-up rare

denominator.recommendation: Use $25M for consistency; note if different denominator used

conservative_annual.methodology: Measured annual wage gains only. No projections.
conservative_annual.audience: Skeptical funders, evaluators, legislators wanting floor estimates

taxpayer_annual.methodology: Tax revenue from wage gains + estimated benefits cost avoidance by FPL tier
taxpayer_annual.audience: State legislators, TANF administrators, taxpayer advocates

lifecycle_with_fade.methodology: Annual wage gains projected over working lifetime with discount rate

societal_comprehensive.methodology: Includes research-based projections of child outcome improvements

key_caveats: RCT validation pending with MEF Associates / Urban Institute
Without RCT, shows association not causation
Building Nebraska Families (only rural TANF RCT) showed zero impact
Benefits savings are estimates, not tracked terminations
Intergenerational effects are projections, not measurements
